title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

text: outlines propose change tphconv. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("e-kotov/tphconv", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: Please note tphconv project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Egor Kotov. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kotov E (2025). tphconv: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data Rasters Vectors. R package version 0.0.0.9000, http://www.ekotov.pro/tphconv/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tphconv: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors},   author = {Egor Kotov},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {http://www.ekotov.pro/tphconv/}, }

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: tphconv R package converting public transport accessibility data Transport Poverty Hub spatial formats. ’s designed : Read gzipped CSV files containing point-based accessibility measures (e.g., number people reachable within 10–20 minutes public transport). Reproject WGS84 (EPSG:4326) coordinates target grid (default EPSG:3035) perform necessary offset data line GISCO INSPIRE grids (https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/grids, https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/population-distribution/population-grids). Rasterize point data onto regular grid (e.g., 1 km resolution) generate vector polygon grids. Convert vector polygons analysis. makes easy integrate transport accessibility information GIS workflows analysis visualization.

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: can install development version tphconv GitHub:

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: Accessibility data provided Transport Poverty Hub Dashboard, requires free EU account log . dashboard allows download precomputed CSV files 1 km grid various countries, including Luxembourg. downloaded file (e.g., ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz), can point tphconv directly.

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: defaults work long data provider change format CSV files. package designed handle standard format used Transport Poverty Hub, arguments can adjusted necessary.

what: Convert a CSV to a Raster
title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
code: library(tphconv)  # Locate the example data shipped with the package tph_file <- system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" )  # Convert to a SpatRaster raster_layer <- tph_to_raster(input_file = tph_file)  library(terra) plot(raster_layer)

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
code: tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".tiff") output_path <- tph_to_raster(   input_file = tph_file,   out_raster_file = tmp_file )  # Check the output g <- terra::rast(output_path) g unlink(tmp_file)  # Clean up temporary file class       : SpatRaster  size        : 80, 55, 1  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) resolution  : 1000, 1000  (x, y) extent      : 4016000, 4071000, 2935000, 3015000  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) coord. ref. : ETRS89-extended / LAEA Europe (EPSG:3035)  source      : file10888755abebd.tiff  name        : opportunities_people  min value   :                    0  max value   :                61065

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: tph_to_raster() – Reads CSV, reprojects, rasterizes accessibility data SpatRaster writes disk.

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: Licensed MIT. Data Transport Poverty Hub Dashboard available CC--4.0, reuse policy outlined EU Commission Decision 12 December 2011.

what: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
text: small gzipped CSV access opportunities measured number people reachable within 10–20 minutes public transport 1 km grid Luxembourg.

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
text: gzipped CSV file 1 600 rows 3 columns: lat dbl; latitude (decimal degrees) lon dbl; longitude (decimal degrees) opportunities (people) dbl; number people reachable 10–20 min public transport

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
text: Transport Poverty Hub © European Union, 1995–2025. Commission’s reuse policy implemented Commission Decision 12 December 2011 reuse Commission documents. Unless otherwise indicated, content owned EU website licensed Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC 4.0) licence. Reuse allowed, provided appropriate credit given changes indicated. information available : Recommendations Member States help tackle transport poverty promote fair, sustainable mobility Transport Poverty Hub (requires login free EU account)

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
text: raw CSV installed :

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
code: f <- system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" ) library(readr) acc <- read_csv(f) #> Rows: 1600 Columns: 3 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> dbl (3): lat, lon, opportunities (people) #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. head(acc) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>     lat   lon `opportunities (people)` #>   <dbl> <dbl>                    <dbl> #> 1  49.5  6.03                     2625 #> 2  49.5  6.36                      375 #> 3  49.5  6.02                     7463 #> 4  49.5  6.03                    10955 #> 5  49.5  6.05                     4087 #> 6  49.5  6.09                     4804

what: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
text: Reads gzipped CSV public transport accessibility data, reprojects point coordinates, rasterizes data onto regular grid. Optionally writes raster disk.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
code: tph_to_raster(   input_file,   out_column_name = NULL,   crs_src = 4326,   crs_dst = 3035,   x_offset = -500,   y_offset = -500,   resolution_m = 1000,   out_raster_file = NULL )

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
text: input_file Character. Path input CSV (gzipped) containing least columns 'lon', 'lat', one numeric data column. out_column_name Character NULL. Name assign data column output raster. NULL (default), original column name CSV used. crs_src Integer character. Source CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 4326. Normally, change , unless know data different CRS. crs_dst Integer character. Destination CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 3035. Normally, change . function relies fact source Transport Poverty Hub input data standardized GISCO grid, internally offests coordinates 500 m align grid. change CRS, may need adjust offset. x_offset Numeric. Offset applied projected coordinates align GISCO () grid; default 500 m. Normally, change , unless know data different CRS. y_offset Numeric. Offset applied projected coordinates align GISCO () grid; default 500 m. Normally, change , unless know data different CRS. resolution_m Numeric. Cell size units destination CRS; default 1000 (1 km). out_raster_file Character NULL. Output filename raster. provided, raster written file (creating directories needed) filename returned. NULL (default), SpatRaster returned directly.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
text: file NULL, terra::SpatRaster object rasterized values. file provided, character string file path returned.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
code: tph_file <- system.file(  "extdata",  "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",  package = "tphconv" ) # Convert a CSV file to a raster r <- tph_to_raster(   input_file = tph_file) library(terra) #> terra 1.8.60 plot(r)   # Convert a CSV file to a raster and write it to disk tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".tiff") out_raster_file <- tph_to_raster(   input_file = tph_file,   out_raster_file = tmp_file ) #' # Check the output file library(terra) r <- rast(out_raster_file) plot(r) unlink(tmp_file)
